item.title: Lee Starts Term With 64% Rating on South Korea Recovery Optimism
item.description: South Korea’s new President Lee Jae Myung started his presidency with a higher approval rating than recent predecessors, as hopes for an economic recovery rise after months of political turbulence.
item.dc:creator: Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: Lee Jae Myung shakes hands with lawmakers at the National Assembly in Seoul on June 26. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Ireland’s Firms Brace for Economic Hit With Quiet Confidence
item.description: Hundreds of companies, 200,000 jobs, billions of euro in corporation tax revenue. Add it all up and Ireland’s reliance on US investment for its economic success is starkly clear.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Duggan

media:content.media:description: Paschal Donohoe at the Future of Finance in Dublin. Photographer: Dean O'Brien/Bloomberg

item.title: Thai Rate Pause Is Lifeline Saved for Turbulence Ahead, BOT Says
item.description: The Bank of Thailand’s decision to leave borrowing costs unchanged this week gives it a “monetary lifeline” to deal with challenges ranging from US tariffs and geopolitical tensions to domestic politics, according to Deputy Governor Piti Disyatat.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Thomas Kutty Abraham

item.title: Thai Finance Chief to Visit US for Trade Talks, Denying 18% Levy
item.description: Thai Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira will visit the US next week for tariff negotiations in an attempt to clinch a trade deal ahead of Washington’s deadline on July 9.
item.dc:creator: Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Pichai Chunhavajira Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: India Earnings Set to Outperform China on Domestic Growth and Tariff Edge
item.description: Indian companies are inspiring more optimism than their Chinese rivals for next earnings season.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Yeo, Harshita Swaminathan

item.title: South Korea Weighing US Request to Boost Defense Spending
item.description: South Korea is in talks with the US about raising its defense spending, a key demand of President Donald Trump as he calls on allies to ramp up their outlays on security and lessen the burden on the US.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin, Soo-Hyang Choi

media:content.media:description: A South Korea Army K1A1 tank fires during a joint live-fire exercise with the US Army in Pocheon, South Korea, in February.

item.title: Tokyo Inflation Eases as Energy Costs Cool Ahead of Election
item.description: Inflation in Tokyo slowed for the first time in four months as energy price gains eased and the municipal government waived some water charges for households ahead of a national election likely to center on the cost-of-living crunch.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: Von Der Leyen Says EU Will Be Ready If US Trade Talks Break Down
item.description: The European Union is prepared for all eventualities in its trade negotiations with the US, including for a breakdown in talks, Ursula von der Leyen said, after discussing the latest proposals from the Trump White House with the bloc’s leaders.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Michael Nienaber, Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission

item.title: Starmer Eases Welfare Cuts in Blow to Budget and His Authority
item.description: Keir Starmer agreed to pare back a divisive £5 billion ($6.9 billion) cut to welfare to quiet a rebellion by his own party, a decision that will likely leave both Britain’s fiscal plans and the prime minister’s own leadership in need of repair.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Ailbhe Rea, Joe Mayes

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer attends the British Chambers of Commerce conference in London on Thursday.

item.title: Treasury Deal Kills ‘Revenge Tax’ That Spooked Wall Street
item.description: The Treasury Department announced a deal with G-7 allies that will exclude US companies from some taxes imposed by other countries in exchange for removing the Section 899 “revenge tax” proposal from President Donald Trump’s tax bill.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Lauren Vella

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury building in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, Aug. 29, 2024. The Treasury Department finalized rules Wednesday on reporting requirements for certain real estate transactions in an effort to crack down on money laundering in the US residential real estate sector.

item.title: Banxico Lowers Rate by Half Point, Opens Door to Smaller Cut
item.description: Mexico’s central bank again cut its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point but it opened the door to smaller cuts going forward as policymakers worry the economy will continue to suffer headwinds after barely avoiding tipping into recession earlier this year.
item.dc:creator: Alex Vasquez, Maya Averbuch

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Mexico (Banxico) headquarters in Mexico City, Mexico, on Wednesday, Nov. 6, 2024. The Mexican peso, which is often seen as the currency most vulnerable to Trump's trade policies, trimmed losses after falling as much as 3.5% earlier — reaching its lowest since August 2022.

item.title: EU Briefs Divided Leaders on Trump’s Counterproposal on Tariffs
item.description: European Union leaders are discussing their response to President Donald Trump’s latest proposal on trade after a briefing from Ursula von der Leyen.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli, Jorge Valero, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Newly manufactured Renault SA vehicles at the port of Marseille, France, on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2025. US President Donald Trump said he would likely impose tariffs on automobile, semiconductor and pharmaceutical imports of around 25%, with an announcement coming as soon as April 2.

item.title: Fed’s Collins Says July Is Likely Too Early for Interest-Rate Cut
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Boston President Susan Collins said she sees at least one interest-rate cut this year, but indicated July would be too early for such a move.
item.dc:creator: Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Boston Fed President Susan Collins.

item.title: Majority of Fed Officials Leaning Against July Interest-Rate Cut
item.description: A flurry of Federal Reserve officials this week made clear they’ll need a few more months to gain confidence that tariff-driven price hikes won’t raise inflation in a persistent way.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Construction on the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. The Federal Reserve unveiled plans to roll back an important capital rule that big banks have said limits their ability to hold more Treasuries and act as intermediaries in the $29 trillion market.

item.title: Trump Decision on Next Fed Chair Not Imminent, White House Says
item.description: The White House said Donald Trump’s decision on a successor for Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell is not near, after the Wall Street Journal reported the president could make a pick as soon as the summer.
item.dc:creator: Kate Sullivan

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC.

item.title: Trump’s Threat of More Tariffs Makes US Trade Partners Wary of Signing Deals
item.description: Tariff negotiations with the Trump administration are running into roadblocks, as partners including Japan, India and the European Union balk at signing deals without knowing how badly they’ll be hit by separate levies on exports including chips, drugs and steel.
item.dc:creator: Malcolm Scott, Yoshiaki Nohara, Shruti Srivastava, Philip Heijmans

item.title: Mortgage Rates in the US Fall for a Fourth Week, Hitting 6.77%
item.description: Mortgage rates in the US fell for a fourth straight week.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Wong

media:content.media:description: Residential homes in Hercules, California, US, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. The Mortgage Bankers Association is scheduled to release mortgage applications figures on June 12.

item.title: Nigeria’s Tinubu Signs New Tax Laws in Latest Reform Push
item.description: Nigerian President Bola Tinubu has signed four new tax laws, marking the latest chapter in his push to reform the economy of Africa’s most populous nation.
item.dc:creator: Nduka Orjinmo, Ruth Olurounbi

media:content.media:description: Bola Ahmed Tinubu

item.title: Zambia to Borrow Extra $624 Million From Domestic Market in 2025
item.description: Zambia will borrow an additional 14.8 billion kwacha ($624 million) from the domestic market to cover a bigger-than-expected shortfall in this year’s budget, Finance Minister Situmbeko Musokotwane said.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill, Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: The city skyline of Lusaka, Zambia.

item.title: Bailey Says Labour’s Payroll Tax Complicates Inflation Fight
item.description: The Labour government’s payroll tax is costing the UK jobs, depressing workers’ earnings and pushing up food prices, Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said as he warned that the risks to inflation remain “two-sided.”
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey at the BCC Global Annual Conference in London. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

item.title: Global Goods Trade Gains as Tariff Fears Speed Imports, WTO Says
item.description: Global merchandise trade accelerated in the World Trade Organization’s latest assessment, with a surge in imports tied to tariff stockpiling outweighing a slowdown in export orders.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: Loaded container ships at Felixstowe port in Felixstowe, UK, on Wednesday, April 9, 2025. The UK doesn’t plan to use a get-out clause to override her fiscal rules, even as the US tariff war roiled global markets, forcing down the pound and UK gilts. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: US Pending Home-Sales Pick Up in May, With Gains Across Regions
item.description: Pending sales of previously owned homes in the US picked up in May after a sharp decline a month earlier, although overall activity remained subdued headed into summer.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: A house under contract in Pasadena, California.

item.title: US Merchandise-Trade Deficit Unexpectedly Widens on Exports Drop
item.description: The US merchandise-trade deficit unexpectedly widened in May on the biggest drop in exports since the onset of the pandemic, while imports were little changed.
item.dc:creator: Mark Niquette

media:content.media:description: The shortfall in goods trade grew 11.1% to $96.6 billion, Commerce Department data showed. Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

item.title: US GDP Revised Lower as Consumers Slash Services Spending
item.description: US consumer spending grew in the first quarter at the weakest pace since the onset of the pandemic on a sharp deceleration in outlays for a variety of services.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Boesler

item.title: OpenAI CEO, Bank Officials to Speak at Fed Bank-Capital Meeting
item.description: The Federal Reserve outlined the agenda for its July 22 conference on banks’ capital requirements, which will feature discussions on the Basel III endgame, the stress testing framework, the capital surcharge for the largest lenders and leverage requirements.
item.dc:creator: Megan Howard

media:content.media:description: Sam Altman Photographer: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

item.title: Fed’s Daly Says Muted Tariff Impact May Open Door to Cut in Fall
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco President Mary Daly said she’s seeing increasing evidence that tariffs may not lead to a large or sustained inflation surge, helping bolster the case for a rate cut in the fall.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva, Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: President of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco Mary Daly

item.title: Recurring US Jobless Claims Jump to Highest Since November 2021
item.description: Recurring applications for US unemployment benefits rose to the highest since November 2021, extending a sharp increase over the past 1 1/2 month and signaling more people are staying out of work for longer.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: Job seekers attend a job fair in Los Angeles. Photographer: Eric Thayer/Bloomberg

item.title: Pakistan Eyes US Trade Deal Soon in Fast-Moving Talks
item.description: Pakistan said trade talks with the US could wrap up next week, as it offers to boost American imports, particularly cotton, amid unusually fast-moving negotiations.
item.dc:creator: Kamran Haider

media:content.media:description: Cotton modules before processing for shipment in Bishop, Texas. Photographer: Eddie Seal/Bloomberg

item.title: Barkin Says Fed Should Wait for Clarity Before Adjusting Rates
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Tom Barkin said he expects tariffs will put upward pressure on prices, and with so much still uncertain, the central bank should wait for more clarity before adjusting interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Reade Pickert, Maria Eloisa Capurro

media:content.media:description: Tom Barkin, president of the Richmond Fed

item.title: India Rate Cuts Still on Table, Says Hawkish Policy-Setter
item.description: A relatively hawkish member of the Indian central bank’s interest rate-setting panel said there is room for borrowing costs to come down, despite a shift in stance in the last policy indicating a tightening bias.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy
